awd_titl_txt: Effects of Teaching Practices on Peer Victimization and Defending Behaviors
awd_abstract_narration:
Peer victimization negatively impacts academic, psychological, and physiological functioning in children. Studies have shown that whether and how children defend their victimized peers has a significant impact on the adjustment of victims. Although much research has focused on individual factors and on class-level dynamics of victimization, less is known about the role of teachers. This project will examine the complex ways in which teachers' characteristics, practices, and actions affect (1) students' beliefs and attitudes; (2) the classroom ecology; and (3) victimization and defending behaviors. Future researchers will be able to use these findings to develop teacher training programs. Findings may also facilitate the development of anti-bullying policies and classroom management strategies.

The study will address the following research questions: What is the association between teaching practices and peer victimization? What is the association between teaching practices and students' desires to defend their victimized peers? How do teaching practices contribute to students' attitudes toward victimization, and are these associations a function of the quality of teacher-student relationships?  Social motivation theoretical models provide an important interpersonal context for socialization by teachers whereas social cognitive theory describes how socialization might contribute to student social cognition and the classroom climate. The researchers will examine reciprocal interactions between teachers and students in fourth and fifth grade classrooms. The project will use a short-term longitudinal design.  Multimethod (e.g., surveys, in-class observations) and multi-informant (teachers, students, trained observers) approaches will be used to gather unique data for multilevel analyses. The use of observational methodology will facilitate capturing teacher-classroom practices as well as teacher-student relations.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This short-term longitudinal study examined the link between teacher practices and class-level bullying and defending behaviors in a diverse sample of 1,060 4th and 5th grade students and 69 teachers in the Southwestern region of the US. Students were surveyed on bullying, victimization, defending behaviors, attitudes towards bullying, perceived classroom norms, expected teacher responses to bullying, empathy, and teacher-student relationships. Teachers were surveyed on classroom management, perceived classroom norms, and handling bullying incidents. The researchers used two methods (surveys and observation) and three reporters (students, teachers, and observers). In addition to surveys completed by students and teachers, trained observers using a structured protocol rated each classroom twice at each time point on emotional support, classroom organization, and instructional support. The use of multiple methods and multiple informants provided rich data.

The project found that classrooms differ in teachers’ handling of bullying, classroom management, emotional support for students, and classroom organization. These differences resulted in four classroom profiles: (1) Authoritative, (2) Neglectful, (3) Overconfident, and (4) Inconsistent. The Authoritative classrooms (n=26) were characterized by good classroom management, evident emotional support and classroom organization in teacher-student interactions, and teacher handling bullying incidents (vs. ignoring). The Neglectful classrooms (n=18) were characterized as having lower emotional support/classroom organization, lower behavioral management, and greater ignoring of bullying incidents. The two remaining clusters were primarily characterized by a lack of correspondence across reporters rather than meaningful and consistent mean-level differences on indicators. The inconsistent cluster (n = 10) was characterized by low levels of teacher-reports but average levels of student-reports of teacher handling of bullying, high observation scores in emotional support and classroom organization, and low levels of teacher-reported behavioral management. The overconfident cluster (n = 9) was characterized by high levels of teacher-reports but low levels of student-reports of teaching handling of bullying, average observational scores, and high levels of teacher-reported behavior management.

Bullying and victimization levels did not change across the two time points. Students’ gender and ethnicity did not predict the changes in bullying or victimization from two time points; neither did teachers’ ethnicity, age, and educational level. The overconfident classrooms had a significant increase in victimization between the two time points. At Time 2, the neglectful classrooms had the lowest defending behaviors. The changes in students’ beliefs supportive of victims or teacher-student relationships between the two time points did not differ in the four classes. 

The findings suggest that teacher-student interactions and teachers’ handling of bullying have an association with student behaviors, namely bullying and victimization. Future research should replicate these findings in areas with different demographics and different grade levels. In addition, recommendations to increase the quality and efficiency of the observation protocol should be evaluated. The results regarding classroom profiles could inform teacher training in bullying prevention and intervention.

The project provided the school-level report to 16 participating schools; the report included student reports and teacher reports by grades from both Time 1 and Time 2. The project also provided unique training opportunities to undergraduate and graduate students, who played critical roles in school-based data collection. They represented several disciplines, such as education, family studies, general psychology, and school psychology. Undergraduate and graduate research assistants visited the participating classrooms in four school districts. They administered student and teacher surveys in classrooms, which offered valuable experiences in interacting with children and communicating with teachers in public schools. Students also completed training in the Classroom Assessment Scoring System and became familiar with important dimensions of classroom interactions between teachers and students; this training led to certification to use the tool. In addition, graduate students had experience with all aspects of the research process, from selecting measures, recruiting participants, administering surveys, and the logistics involved in working with multiple schools and teachers. They contributed to data management and analyses and presented the findings at professional conferences.
